author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, that is pure speculation.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we *really* want to solve this problem with a real solution that isn't ETH 2, I think the best option is conditional transactions.  We would need to dedicate some research mindshare to figuring out how to make it work exactly, but I *believe* there is a solution there.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, we would need to do additional research (first) to verify that my theory is correct that a large percentage of gas is spent on no-op transactions, and providing people a mechanism for *not* including no-op transactions (which they don't want included in the first place) would alleviate a large amount of gas demand pressure.

author: sky.cactus
content: There exists a set of transactions where no state is changed other than submitter nonce is increased and gas accounting (deduct from sender, add to miner).  These transactions serve no purpose, and almost always the user doesn't actually want these transactions included in the chain (they just cost them money).

author: sky.cactus
content:
The most common scenarios where these transactions occur are:
1. Cancellations (0 ETH send to self with higher gas price and same nonce).
2. Front-runners and back-runners who "lost" the race.

author: sky.cactus
content: For (1), I don't think we can (or want to) drop those since it means that user's cannot "cancel" transactions.  For (2), I think everyone would benefit if we figured out a way to simply *not* include them.

author: sky.cactus
content: The proposed (not complete) solution here is to allow for conditional transactions, where the user can say "only execute this transaction if it is immediately after transaction hash X" or "only include this transaction if `block.timestamp >= X` and `block.parent.timestamp < X`.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think this solution is reasonable as an emergency hotfix, but I think it is *more reasonable* than AA or ETH2 in terms of engineering costs and it would be *possible* to get it into Berlin if we really wanted and dedicated necessary R&D to it.

author: shamatar
content: Checks like block.timestamp >= X and block.parent.timestamp < X are very reasonable and I do not see a direct downside of not implementing it. Does anyone know a reason why it was not in the original WP or any general arguments against it?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!381789485777682434> It introduces a minor DoS risk that needs to be solved/addressed or at least evaluated.

author: sky.cactus
content: Someone can submit a transaction that is only valid after some time in the distant future, or a transaction that is only valid up until 4 seconds from now.  In both cases, the transaction is technically valid and will propagate (costing the network resources to gossip the transaction), but the transaction ultimately will never be included in a block and thus the sender will never have to pay for it.

author: sky.cactus
content: Currently, all transactions that are valid cost the sender some minimum amount of money.

author: sky.cactus
content: The best solution I can come up with to addressing this problem is something like hashcash, but these transactions are often incredibly time sensitive, which makes hashcash not a great option.

author: axic3354
content:
Well you could have different kids:
- If not_before timestamp is set, it must be X seconds in the future at least (e.g. 2 blocks from "now")
- If not_after timestamp is set, it must be less than Y seconds into the future at most (e.g. 1 month worth of blocks from today)
- And if you set both fields, both of these restrictions apply.

author: axic3354
content: Wouldn't that "solve" most of these concerns?

author: axic3354
content: But what is the point of `not_before`?

author: sky.cactus
content: Liquidation bots very often want to be "the first transaction in the first block on or after timestamp X".  There can be extremely heavy competition for this slot, as liquidations can yield tens of thousands of dollars or even sometimes hundreds of thousands of dollars in profits (millions if there is a bug like Black Thursday).

author: shamatar
content: Well, "not before" is indeed dangerous and spams a pool, but one can introduce a DDoS protection for propagation of transactions based on "valid_until - now"

author: sky.cactus
content: This results in 10s, hundreds, or even thousands of transactions being submitted and all but 1 of them being no-op transactions.

author: shamatar
content: I'm not talking about bots here but more about normal users

author: sky.cactus
content: The goal with a proposal like this is to make it so all but one of those transactions just gets dropped, rather than ending up in a block.

author: axic3354
content: Why is it good allowing not-immediately-executable transactions to fill up the pool?

author: axic3354
content: Even if they are not maliciously expiring in 2 seconds, they could be sticking there for months waiting to be executed.

author: sky.cactus
content: These bots *will* fill up the pool no matter what we do because it is a huge profit opportunity.  I want them to not *also* fill up a block.

author: axic3354
content: Well, right now they have to compete and send many transactions. `not_before` would not make it better or worse for them, but opens another option to fill up the pool with waste.

author: shamatar
content: This sounds more like speculative execution, and miners may still want to include such transactions to collect fees?

author: shamatar
content: Not executing transaction based on a state-based predicate is non-trivial

author: sky.cactus
content: A combination of conditions could get us to a place where only one of the transactions actually gets mined.  `not_before` alone would help because it means bots aren't having to spam multiple transactions because they don't know which block they'll land in, but `not_before` combined with `must_be_first_in_block` and `parent_block_must_be_before` would make it so only a single transaction was actually valid.

author: sky.cactus
content: For high value liquidations, it is not unheard of to see multiple blocks completely full (e.g., a block before, the block of, and a block after) of just liquidation bots competing for a single space as the first transaction in that middle block.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Not executing transaction based on a state-based predicate is non-trivial
<@!381789485777682434> Yeah, it totally is.  The idea would be to have a constrained set of conditions that don't depend on state.  We won't get state dependent transactions until AA at the earliest I think.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> This sounds more like speculative execution, and miners may still want to include such transactions to collect fees?
<@!381789485777682434> Definitely, which is why the only way I think this will work is if we make it so miners *can't* include all of those transactions.

author: shamatar
content: This in general is a set of specific options for arbitrage and front/backrunning. I think <@456226577798135808> had an opinion about transaction predicates

author: shamatar
content: What is `parent_block_must_be_before` exactly?

author: sky.cactus
content: It would be used in conjunction with "this_block_must_be_after".

author: sky.cactus
content: The idea is that sometimes opportunities present at certain points in time, and the opportunity is available to the first transaction in the first block after a certain point in time.

author: sky.cactus
content: So what you want is for one transaction to be valid for that slot, and all other transactions competing for that slot to be invalid (dropped).

author: sky.cactus
content:
So the transaction would say, "only include this transaction if it is:
1. First transaction in block.
2. The parent block's timestamp is before X
3. This block's timestamp is after or equal to X

author: shamatar
content: What I mean is does it mean like `this_block_must_be_after_some_tx_hash` or after what exactly?

author: shamatar
content: Oh, time based, ok

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.  There is a *different* set of opportunities around "must be immediately before transaction X" and "must be immediately after transaction X".

author: sky.cactus
content: (front running, back running, sandwiching, etc.)

author: sky.cactus
content: These also can see huge amounts of competition that fills up blockspace, where only one transaction does anything and the rest are no-ops.
